Posts.Content: After I complained to my oncologist about similar symptoms, he said it was quite common due to radiation and recommended tylenol and ice when I had a flare.  (My radiation was in 2005 and still get occasionally when I exert myself.)
Posts.Title: Breast cancer and rib cage pain

Posts.Content: Mine was found by a mammogram, it could not be felt at all.  Though it's been 9 years since my BC, I can completely understand the anxiety you're experiencing.  I have a very aggressive GYN who now prescribes an annual mammo along with an opposing 6 month MRI.  I have my next MRI on Monday and even after 9 years, my nerves are a mess for a few weeks leading up to each test and it triples waiting for results.  It sounds like you're going to a center where they are very cautious and thorough and that's very good, you want someplace where they investigate fully. I pray for good results and for peace whatever the results.
Posts.Title: grape size hard mass, waiting on core biopsy results

Posts.Content: As I await the results of my fourth biopsy since BC treatment in 2005, I just want to say thank you to all of you out there who are supporting each other, providing a place where we can share our fears, ask for answers or advice the medical community is unable or unwilling or too overburdened to provide.  This is an amazing community and I hope for peace and strength for all who are taking this journey - one which we never wanted to take, but during which we find courage we never thought we possessed.  Bless you all!
Posts.Title: Thank you for support

Posts.Content: I guess I could be considered an expert on the MRI w/contrast having had one annually for the past 9 years post-BC.  In fact, I'm having my next on Monday. For me, the worst part is getting the IV started.  I did not have a port during chemo, so my veins are not the best.  The noise, if you anticipate it, is not too bad and I have very sensitive hearing.  One thing I would like to pass along from my GYN (the prescribing doctor.)  He indicated, when we first started MRI's, that they have a higher than normal incidence of false positives on dense breast tissue due to the high detail they reveal.  He told me this so if a biopsy was called for, I'd not automatically panic.  I've had 4 biopsies since 2005 as a result of MRI or mammo images and do I still have a case of the nerves til results are known?  You betcha! Good luck and try and stay calm.
Posts.Title: Breast MRI w/Contrast

Posts.Content: I think you tell what you feel comfortable sharing and to whom you feel like telling it.  I had folks that were just plain curious, and they were the ones I felt least likely to share my story. I think they're the ones who live with an unspoken fear of "what if it was me?" and hope by getting as much info as possible, they can forstall their own fears.  This is your body, your journey, not a learning experience for others. One of the hardest parts of this journey is feeling like you've lost all control.  Well, this is one area you can control.  If someone gets too intrusive, simply look them in the eye and say you're uncomfortable with the discussion and would like to drop it.  Don't worry about their feelings - now, it's yours that count!  Share only what you feel comfortable sharing.  I put some of these unwanted questions on the same level as strangers who go up to a pregnant woman and touch her stomach.  Privacy is your privilege.
Posts.Title: New dx- need advice re: what to tell/ not tell

Posts.Content: That's how we all feel..once things start moving, you feel like you're going forward.  Standing still is the hardest!
Posts.Title: Bra suggestions following lumpectomy

Posts.Content: That's what is so wonderful about this forum.  Those of those that have walked the same road before want to make it better for those who are traveling it traveling it today.  Anytime, my friend.  I pray someday it'll be you comforting another.
Posts.Title: Bra suggestions following lumpectomy

Posts.Content: May I suggest a relaxation technique that's gotten me through both BC and afib?  It's especially helpful when your mind is consumed with thoughts of "what if."  Meditation has been a lifesaver for me.  Rather than try and teach the technique, someone new would be helped by an audio assist.  There is a website,www.healthjourneys.com, and I'm recommending Bellruth Naperstak's cd's/mp3 recordings.  They walk you through relaxation and, more importantly, give you something to concentrate on beyond your procedures and the fright that comes with not knowing what lies ahead.  Hoping for good blessings, Sandy
Posts.Title: Bra suggestions following lumpectomy

Posts.Content: Nine years after lumpectomy and 4 later biopsies, I can recommend the Champion front zip sports bra.  After all biopsies, they even recommend a compression bra to ease the discomfort of "jiggling."  (I'm a 36C-D)  The zipper is very easy to deal with, more so than the hook-type, I think. You're also going to want to probably ditch underwire bras.  Depending on the lympectomy site and how many lymph nodes are taken, you may find underwires uncomfortable. There is one fact I'd like to make you, and any other BC radiation patients aware of.  Certainly if you're a larger breast size, you want to always wear a really good sports bra when exercising. Radiation changes the muscle/ligament structure in your breast, making it easier to strain those muscles.  The first time it happened to me, it scared me til I learned it's another of those "oh, didn't we tell you that" facts the doctors neglect to mention. Holding you up in prayer for best results!
Posts.Title: Bra suggestions following lumpectomy

Posts.Content: I don't remember the exact saying, but to paraphrase, every step is making you stronger, wiser and putting you one step further along in the journey.  I'm so sorry for the pain you experienced and hope it's lessoned some.  I presume they gave you meds to counteract the nausea?  And, be sure to understand and follow their instructions on caring for your port, especially when it's so new.  Holding you up, Milliemom!
Posts.Title: Bra suggestions following lumpectomy

Posts.Content: I hope your radiation is close by, you're on the table for, oh, about 20 seconds!  and the 7 weeks does really pass quickly!Though they may have some salve they recommend, I found pure aloe vera was very good for the sunburn you acquire during radiation.  And, while chemo does change your eating patterns and what foods appeal to you, they have drugs which help you manage the side effects effectively.  You are strong, stronger than you can even imagine.  Believe in yourself and believe you are going to beat it.  Positive energy turned inwards is one of your most effective "drugs" during this journey.  Blessings my friend!
Posts.Title: Bra suggestions following lumpectomy

Posts.Content: I had the full 33 days.  Likely, if necessary, you'll do chemo before radiation.  I had an estrogen positive tumor, so my chemo was different...but then, after 9 years, all courses of treatment have changed signmificantly - for the better!  From the "old" days when you were in isolation with chemo to now relaxing in a recliner, receiving your infusion, while visiting with others or reading or listening to music.  It's not a journey any of us want to take, but you'll find you're a much stronger person that you'd every dreamed.  Good luck and blessings, my friend!
Posts.Title: Bra suggestions following lumpectomy

Posts.Content: That's what is so wonderful about this forum, we can all share not only symptoms, concerns, diagnosis and treatment..we can share with others when treatment gives good outcome.  When my brother had successfull stage 3 PC surgery, I stood up in church and announced, saying "I know there's someone here today who needs to hear this."  Your journey is a wonderful thing to share!  Continued good health and happiness!
Posts.Title: encouragement for all

Posts.Content: I used to call mine "chemo legs", feels like your muscles somehow became disconnected from your legs.  I know it's difficult to walk when you're so weak, but encourage her to do some minor walking around the house, it'll help retain as much muscle tone as possible.  Look up BRAT diet, it's one recommended for those with extreme diarrhea, and she may be able to tolerate it.  I also drank lots of Gatorade to bring up the electrolytes I was losing with the diarrhea.  That contributes to your legs feeling like rubber.  I know now I'd have been smarter to use coconut water as it doesn't have all the sugar in Gatorade.  Try using it in a fruit smoothie with bananas maybe?
Posts.Title: Please help deal with extreme weakness

Posts.Content: Dear Mazuret, each of us reacts differently to being told we have BC, and like your wife, I'm an "A."  I was angry that I was diagnosed and had to put the life I'D planned on hold.  Not angry, really pissed that I no longer had control or was in charge of my own destiny.  We "A's" don't give up control well, as I'm sure you knew before she was diagnosed.  With more experience, I now know treatment is as hard on the caregiver as the patient, as caregivers we don't know how to help, and high achievers hate to ask for help.  It's just more evidence that our plans for our life are now inalterably changed.  I don't know where she's receiving treatment, but do they have any kind of counseling available?  Not necessarily for her, but for you and the kids?  Maybe the only words of comfort I can give you are that her anger is not because of you or the kids or even really directed at you or the kids.  It's because of what's happening in her world, her anger is directed at the cancer that's robbed her of her singular right to direct her life.  The very fact that you're looking for guidance shows what an amazing man you are and how truly lucky your wife is to have you along on this awful journey.  God bless you, your children and your wife..who I pray finds peace and acceptance of the situation soon.
Posts.Title: Extreme anger / breast cancer

Posts.Content: Now that I'm seeing advice coming from others, I am wondering if you can share what you've written on this message board with your wife and what support we other "A's" are offering?  Her life right now is centered on just getting herself through this journey.  I am sure she has no idea how her effort to cope is having such an awful impact on you and the kids.
Posts.Title: Extreme anger / breast cancer

Posts.Content: I know that there is a lot of bad press out there about Armidex, but I'll share my story with you.  I was diagnosed in 2005, literally making me a very early user of it.  I was 60 years old, and had a T1, intermediate grade tumor, no lymph involvement and clear margins.  I'd had radiation and I did chemo because of the grading of the tumor. During the 5 years I took Armidex, I had no side effects:  no weight gain, no loss of bone density and no ill effects.  Though I continue to have good density, I am now a multi-joint arthritis sufferer - just had my right hip replaced in Nov. (But, I'd fallen in 2002 and was warned it was likely I'd develop arthritis in that joint due to the severity of the fall.)  Do I think Armidex contributed to my arthritis - possibly.  Would I take it now realizing that my multi-joint arthritis may be due to the Arimidex - yes.  I took it for the same reason I elected to do chemo - I wanted the very best chances of survival. Best of luck to you, Sandy
Posts.Title: Afraid to begin Arimidex
